case.name: IGT v Commissioner of Patents [2008] FCA 15 (17 January 2008)

citphrases.citphrase: [ database search ] [ name search ] [ recent decisions ] [ noteup ] [ lawcite ] [ help ] a goninan & co ltd v the commissioner of patents & anor [1997] fca 424 (23 may 1997) patents
application for second extension of time for filing of evidence
factors to be taken into account
whether the commissioner of patents is under a duty to grant an extension of time where evidence relevant to the opposition proceedings is immediately available
whether the commissioner is bound to consider the significance of evidence on which the party seeking an extension wishes to rely in opposition proceedings.

citances.sentence: The Federal Court decision, IGT v Commissioner of Patents , [2008] FCA 15 , though warns against elevating the significance of the evidence to a determinative factor effectively excluding consideration of other matters.

On 17 January 2008 consent orders were issued by the Federal Court setting aside the decision and remitting the matter back to the Commissioner ( IGT v Commissioner of Patents [2008] FCA 15). The reason for setting aside the decision was that:
"that the delegate ... could be taken to have elevated the significance of the evidence to a determinative factor effectively excluding consideration of other matters. I emphasise that I do not find that this was the legal effect of the delegate's remark. However, the possibility of error which [IGT and Aristocrat] have accepted, is sufficient to support the consent order which is now sought".
